author: Nilsmens

description.text: I had and idea for a stackable stencil that could be printed on a 3d printer.  Unfortunately I don\'t have one yet (please help me w/ that makerbot!!).  This is also my first attempt at modeling in Blender so take it easy on me.  I thought it would be handy to create a stencil that could be anything you wanted it to be.  You should be able to scale this to as large as your build platform.  Hopefully there won\'t be issues with warping, it may require a heated platform. Sadly I can\'t test it myself.  These should be able to stack together for storage. You should be able to add any design you want to the blank stencil. I also made a couple simple samples.  I hope to refine this model some but I think its a decent starting point.  Hope you enjoy it.

title: Poteau beton avec luminaire LED (Concrete pole with LED luminaire)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hauteur total : 128mm
Hauteur du luminaire :100mm

Pour le câblage de la LED, utiliser de préférence une led de 5mm blanche.
Couder ces pattes a 90° pour les souder au fils de cuivre.

Les fils de cuivre utilisé sont ceux récupérés sur la bobine d'un transformateur de récupération.
Je vous conseille de passer les fils un par un par le bas du poteau en le remontant jusqu'au 14eme trou, puis a l'aide d'une pointe fini de courbé le bout afin de le guide vers la courbure de la console du luminaire (Voir photo)
Celui ci et recouvert d'origine par un vernis isolant , il suffira de chauffer l’extrémité avec un briqué pour pouvoir ensuite le souder a la led.

Sous le plateau sera installé une resistance de 820 ohm qui sera soudé en serie a un des fils .
De nombreux exemple existe sur internet pour cabler une led en 12v .

description.text: My wife broke the quick latch knob of her embroidery hoop, could not find a model already on thingiverse so build a quick one using ThinkerCad, and for being the first iteration is pretty useable

Printer:

Monoprice select mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50

Notes:

It is the first release, feel free to improve it

Replacement part

First scanned the original broke part using a flatbed scanner
Edited it with gimp to remove all borders and (glue the parts together)
Once i got an usable contour, exported it to png, and used https://www.vectorizer.io/ free vectorization web service to transform it to svg
Imported the part on thinkercad, added heigh, and made the cuts according to the gaps on the figure.

Part printed just fine on monoprice slect mini in less tan 30 minutes with .175 layer height, 0.8mm borders, and 50% of infill.

Hi Makers,

i designed this cause it come to see... i tune my settings while printing and then... by mistake i hit the reset button..... BEEP.. BEEP ... 12 hour print is gone....

that thing should not happen.... load, print, glue a 6mm magnet in the small hole and this nightmare will never happen to you

Thanks!
PaNiC

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

no need to

Post-Printing

you will need to glue a 6mm magnet into the small hole as you see on the picture and you are ready to go...

Enjoy and be save ;-)

author: denis94

description.text:
I designed and built this trophy for the fantasy football leagues. This trophy has 4 secret magnetic mechanisms.

In order to open the top lid of football on top;

  • unlock the "stand door" to open by using “access key”
  • pull the “bodkey” out of the “bodykey” and turn the “bodkey” 180 degree then put it back in to unlock the “bodykey”
  • once the “bodykey” unlocks, rotate the “bodykey” 180 degree to unlock the “latch key” and pull it out
  • use the “the bodkey” to unlock the top lid to open
    There are two different hinges in the trophy:
  • Hinge in the football; I used 1/8” metal rod x 2” long.
  • Hinge in the “stand door”; Each hinge uses 2 opposing 1/8” x ¼” magnets.
    There are 4 latch mechanism; it comprised of a 1/8” x ¼” magnet stacked on a 3/16” x 1/32” magnet. This stacked magents goes in the large opening in the latch. Another 1/8” x ¼” magnet goes behind the stacked magents so that when installed it opposes to each other.
    The bodkey, access key and crankshaft key use 3/8” x 1/8” magnet.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm layer

Infill:

15% to 20%

Bill of Material

qty (14) Ø1/8" x 1/4" lg magnet
qty (5) Ø3/16" x 1/32" thickness

qty (1) Ø1/8" x 2" lg metal rod (can be found at Home Depot)
qty(1) Ø3/16" x 15.62" lg metal rod (can be found at Home Depot)

qty(19) M3x0.5mm x 10mm lg Alloy Steel Socket Head Screws
qty(5) M3x0.5 x 12mm lg Alloy Steel Socket Head Screws

description.text: After "loosing" my FlexRC Ascent in tall grass several times (once took 45 minutes to find) I decided to try a Loc8tor. A gent at my RC club had them on his plane and said they do work. So I designed a top mount for the Ascent. It sort of looks like a radar antenna up top! No adverse affects on flight times or punch outs. The entire unit with mount and zip tie is slightly under 10gm. A cheap insurance policy. It has already paid for itself in lost flight time. I can locate the downed Ascent in tall grass in a minute or two. The unit has its own battery so even with a battery eject, it works perfectly.

title: Renkforce RF100 Y-Axis damage prevention clip Version 2 (experimental)

description.text:
This is Version 2 of my Renkforce RF100 damage prevention / protection clip.

Version 1 is a plug and play clip and can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2447813 Here you can find detailed information about the RF100 axis problem, too.

The main problem of my first clip is that it seems to be only working on printers where the axis is not bended yet. So I designed this one which might work on bended axis, too.

This version is using two M3x16 (or M3x20) screws and nuts. So it is adjustable to the printer, but some more difficult to install.

Installation:

  1. Like Version 1 just clip the top part to the printer housing next to the engine.
  2. Use the screw insertion helper to insert the back screw with the head on top.
  3. Insert the front screw with the head on top.
  4. Insert the bottom linear bearing part onto the screws.
  5. Insert one nut on each screw and turn them by hand carefully.
  6. Use the printer menu to move the Y-axis four till five times. If the printer makes noise, loose the nuts a bit.

Note: On the photo the screws are inserted with the nuts on top. It was only experimental for testing. Insert the screws with the nuts on bottom and head on top, because of if the screws are to long, they will stuck and might damage something.

This item is made for protecting the Y-axis of bending, but also to hopefully help bending it back to nearly straight position. If your axis to bended too much, install the tool and print some hours. If it is making noise, loose the nuts a bit. If not, try to tight them a bit.

Use this item on your own risk!

The photos are showing the previous version. The downloadable files are the actual ones.

2x M3x16 or better M3x20 screws
2x M3 nut optional teflon spray to oil the printed bearing

title: Dishwasher Clean/Dirty Sign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 8/22/2017: I added a new two-part version of the sign (labeled "separated") that allows you to color the letters using filament switching, or simply have an easier time painting them.

A simple sliding clean/dirty sign for dishwashers. The two pieces can be snapped together (requires a bit of force) for a permanent connection. I like to paint the top of the letters for contrast, as well. Attach using standard adhesive strips.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print in the given orientation. You might be able to print this without supports, but I like to add them just to support the upper ledge, since it can cause the sliding action's performance to degrade if it isn't.

comments.text: I don't trust my hand to paint the letter 'tops' without smoothing into the background.
comments.author: Tatte

comments.text: So it turned out I found a small chunk of time this morning to modify the file and create a two-part version, which is now available along with the original version. I haven't had a chance to test it yet, but the new version should make it much easier to color the letters, either via filament switching or simply by making it easier to paint/color the top surfaces. You could even just spray paint the whole thing and then sand the tops of the letters.
comments.author: Tatte

comments.text: Thanks.  I'll give it a try later today
comments.author: berky93

comments.text: I've got a version in the works but unfortunately other projects have taken up most of my time. I find that the easiest way to color the tops of the letters is to simply use a metallic permanent marker or paint pen -- the one pictured was colored using a silver Sharpie.

This is a filament roller that fits nicely on top of the IKEA Stuva Box. It can hold multiple spools at once (if you need).

I used a 1 meter aluminium tube, which I cut in half - change the length to your needs. To properly fit the provided adapter the tube should have 22mm inner and 25mm outer diameter. If you need different diameter, just write down in the comments, I'm happy to help out and providing you the adapted STL file.

Further I used 4x 624ZZ (4x13x5mm) bearings and appropriate axels.

STL for simons cat. used mine as a fridge magnet with a neodyme magnet glued on the back

Because why wouldn't you just keep adding fans?

I've built this part because I had touble printing a metallic PLA in a warm room. Adding more cooling definitely helped.

The fan shroud used in the picture can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2493756
The fans should be in a push-pull configuration.

You will need at least two M3 screws (10mm or larger) and Nuts.
The fins inside the front piece are there to create a clean airflow path around the hotend cooling grill in the shape of an U. They fit rather tightly and might need some cleanup after printing if you experience stringing or blobbing.
You most likely don't need this mod, though. the original e3d v6 fan provides enough cooling in most cases.

Simple little fan mount for dual 40mm fans. One for the extruder and one for the hotend itself.
I have printed both version 1 and 2 and both work really well and fit perfectly. The mounting holes are only 3.2mm so you may need to drill them out a bit depending on your printers tolerances.

I printed mine out of PLA, without changing the orientation with no supports and 20% infill and it came out nearly perfect. You will likely need to cool the part while it's printing or the "duct" will have holes in it where the plastic sags because of the high angles.

Since this is close to the hotend you should probably use either PETG or ABS, both of which have better heat tolerances.

description.text:
This is a typical Dutch traffic light you encounter near buslanes, and intersections.
I made this model for a time management function. As you can see in the pictures a fully functional traffic light.

When the RED light is lit you may not interput that person.
When RED and Orange are lit, it will take an X amount of time before he is availible.
When GREEN is lit the person is availible

The Arduino code is included. on request i can sent you the wiringscheme.
Parts List:
Bunch of wires
2x 10k Ohm resistors
3 x 220 Ohm resistors
2 x push buttons
1 x Attiny 2313 (programmed with arduino, on how i did this, there is a .txt file included with a link to a tutorial that worked for me)

title: Makelangelo 5 printed parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERG68q-nm8E

Makelangelo 5 is the latest edition of the open source drawing robot that hangs on a whiteboard, window, or mirror to draw with a sharpie. Takes up no room on a table! Put one in your class and if a student is staring out the window, they're staring at the machine. Learn the basics of CNC without the burning hot danger nozzle, and upcycle the parts when you're ready to make a real 3D printer.

You can get a fully assembled and tested makelangelo or figure it out and make your own. It's open source!

Please share whatever you make on the marginally clever forums so we can get it to all the Makelangelo fans.

Thanks!

Grit

Makelangelo has been slowly evolving for nearly a decade. When I designed these parts I used Fusion360 and many many repeat prints.

I had many people double check my work and we went through many iterations of small changes. We stop making improvements!

title: Tripod removable mount for almost anything

description.text:
I wanted to build a 1.2 > 5.8 ghz relay and mount it on a tripod.

All the design found here was using a nut to put inside the print for mounting on the tripod. I don't have it and did'nt want to buy it either.

So I tested if simply printing a hole and screwing it to the tripod work, and it worked !

You can use it for many thing, the removable part have four screw hole to fix an object to it but I provide the freecad file, so nothing stop you from modifying it to… make a phone stand or anything else.

The moving part is kind of loose, so if you want it to be really tight , don't hesitate to reduce a bit the inner radius. Its also depend of your nozzle of course, I used a 0.4 here.

I printed it with 30% infill because I wanted to be strong, but you can try at 15%, I'm pretty sure it'll work just fine.

Printer:

Dagoma DiscoEasy200

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

nozzle 0.4mm

After printing the fixed part, you need to screw it to the tripod first.

Make sure to go slowly, the more straight possible and forcing a lot on it.

Once the thread is done, its really easy to unscrew/screw it, and its really strong, I would even say as strong as metal nut…

author: eephyne

print_settings.Notes:: Important: Generate your own adapter using the OpenScad file!

description.text:
My very first THING!
It's a simple adapter for the filament spool. The STL supplied has a center hole of 21 mm diameter and an outer diameter of 53.5 mm.It fits a center pin of 20 mm and a spool diameter of 53.7 mm.
It is only supplied as an example design, it will probably not fit your spool.

The idea is to have a snug fit to the spool and a loose fit for the center tube.

Be sure to measure both ends of the spool because it is not certain that they have the same diameter! On my spool they differed about 0.7 mm...

Use tolerance of about 0.1-0.2 mm for outer diameter and 1 mm for center hole.

Measure and change values in the OpenScad file and generate your own adapters.

2017-09-03: New version of spooladapter.scad. Enter exact dimensions and tweak tolerances if you want to. Default tolerances set to 1.0 mm for hole and -0.2 mm för outer diameter
2017-09-04: New versions of both scad-file and stl
2017-09-17: Should work with Customizer too

comments.author: jamesd256

comments.text:
I haven't tested well mine knife so far but I spent some time looking for best solutions to use it. I found that using drag knife we have to modify gcode - use "corner action". It's well illustrated on Donek's web side. There is also excell sheet with macro adding corner action code. In few words - in the corners we have to pull up knife to the top of the material (cutting depth tenth millimetre), make additional move (corner action) to position blade direction and put down to cutting deep.
Look at it: http://donektools.com/free-cnc-router-software/links-2/
This video shows how it works - mention action in the corners (knife going up and down): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lzfd0jsw0Ro
Cutting material at once (one pass) forgives some bearing loose.

This is my Ultimaker 2+ door . Easy to install and disassemble, just pull it up.
You can mount it without modifying the printer Frame, fix it with 3 screws on the left or the right side.

Parts needed:
4mm acrylic glass 270x290mm,
hinge_door: super glue to fix it on the acrylic glass (door_drawing)
hinge_printer: 3x M3 flat head screw 25mm;
Lock:
2 metal springs 16mm x 5mm Diameter
4x M3 cheese head screw 18mm
1x M3 chese head screm 20mm

To install the lock, see the door_drawing file below for the dimensions. Then fix it according to the drawing with a clamp, drill the 4 holes 4mm and attach it to mark the breakthrough.
I made the cut with my dremel.
Then attach the parts lock_lever and lock_outside on the front of the door, screw thew inner bolt part to the lock_lever. Put the metal springs in the provided holes and add the last part lock_inside. You need a screw driver to get the spring in the hole from the lock_inside part.

author: Slyngblade

title: Nikon D90 - Solar Eclipse Glasses Mount

description.text:
I designed this the morning of August 21st 2017 in preparation for the eclipse and wanting to take some photos on my Nikon D90.

I built this specifically for the Nikon D90, but it should work on any camera lens that has 70mm of width at the front of the lens. Worked great for me with a 55-300mm lens.

Once the print is done, you'll need a pair of solar eclipse glasses to slide through the cutout. I would recommend nothing thicker than 0.80mm in thickness. I had to wiggle mine through but it ultimately worked out perfect.

In reality, you could of course use anything else as a filter as long it is 0.80mm or less in thickness and ~38mm in height.

I hope that someone else finds this useful!

Solar Eclipse Glasses

I measured my solar eclipse glasses to be 0.79mm at the thickest point, so I made the cutout 0.85mm thick so that you can slide it in without too much resistance.

The cutout for the lens measures 41.50mm by 26.50mm. Again, this was based on my measurements of the solar eclipse glasses I had available to me.

Optional: Sand down the interior ring

In order to fit this on my Nikon D90 lens, I needed to sand the interior ring down ever so slightly. Did 3 passes around the whole interior ring with some sandpaper I had lying around. Worked fantastic after that.

author: alimag

description.text:
Briks First est un jeu type "Dominos" en 3D. On peut y joueur à plat (facile) ou en mode "construction". Il faut faire correspondre les couleurs des côtés pour marquer des points (voir règle en PDF).
Il est possible d'imprimer plusieurs briques et plusieurs côtés pour gagner du temps.
Attention ! Il y a des côtés blancs (jokers) et noirs (interdit de construire) mais il n'y a pas de brique blanche et/ou noires.
Il faut pour un jeu :

  • 6 briques bleues, 6 briques jaunes, 6 briques rouges, 6 briques vertes
  • 12 côtés noirs, 24 côtés blancs, 36 côtés bleus, 36 côtés jaunes, 6 côtés rouges, 36 côtés verts
    Et un distributeur à briques (optionnel)
    Amusez vous bien !

Mise en place du poussoir

Le poussoir est à coller derrière les deux parties (bas et haut) du distributeur collées elles aussi.
Egalement à coller les deux parties du coulissant.

Le couvercle coulissant est en deux parties.
Lorsque le coulissant est glissé dans un sens : le distributeur est fermé (pour transport)
Lorsque le coulissant est glissé dans l'autre sens, le distributeur laisse l'ouverture nécessaire pour tirer une brique (en poussant sur le poussoir collé derrière le distributeur).

title: Ford Mondeo mk3 keyring key chain

description.text:
Printed in pla with bed temperature of 60c and extruder 190c with a skirt 4mm out.
I find 25% infil is best for strength and robustness.

I guess if you used abs or something flexible or stronger you could get away with using less.

Takes about 7 minutes to print approximately
Looks good with a coat of epoxy on the face which gives it a nice shine and fills in any gaps it may have.

i designed this in 3 parts:

Base is basically a rectangle 70mm x 30mm x 2mm You just create the object out of a primitive shape and you need a cylinder 1.5 or 2 radius and any height you want. you can use this to cut the hole in the base. you could alternatively use a drill i guess.

The car is taken from a picture made into a stencil and placed on top of the base this is 3mm tall

The writing is 2mm tall and also placed on the base.

You can change all of these sizes to suit your needs it can easily be scaled up a lot bigger but i wouldn't recommend doing it much smaller as the details get a bit lost in the printing.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

70 x 20 x 5mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Ford Mondeo logo keyring Designed by myself based on a vehicle.
NGSS

learn to create a keyring My take on making a keyring based on a vehicle, i hope to teach people how this can be done, it does take some time to put this together for some people but its a fairly simple design over all with 3 basic elements combined together.

needed 3d designer software
3d slicer software
3d printer
filament plastic. pla or abs recommended although others may work just as well :)

title: Macro Photography LED Ring Light with dimmer

description.text:
This is a Macro Photography LED Ring Light that has a built-in variable brightness dimmer. I've been enjoying it for a while now so I thought there might be some macro photographers out there who would like it too. It's based around a 12 volt led ring light that you see fitted around some modern car headlights like the ones on Audi's. It's inexpensive to make and the results are good! It's also good as a soft fill light for close up beauty shots and gives a nice reflection in the models eyes. It works for close up foodie shots too :)
It fits from a 60mm up to a 85mm diameter macro lens.
The battery life is under an hour but if you don't leave it on when you're not using it you can get a lot of use out of it... better still, use rechargeables.
All the parts have eBay and other links in the post printing section below.

You can see a showcase and DIY video here:-
https://youtu.be/RxrZJ8-1mmw

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

You can see all my videos on my YouTube Channel, ScottyMakesStuff here:-
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChDeVchB6CCF--0wQQYNIhQ
https://twitter.com/ScottyMakesStuf
https://www.instagram.com/scottymakesstuff/

author: LarzJ

title: ANET A8 Z-saver and X leveling tool (mechanical end stop)

description.text:
When installing an auto leveling sensor to the ANET, the z-min switch is replaced by the z-probe.

In case of any problem on the z-probe, nothing will stop the Z axis and it will crash into the bed and push on the glass directly with the nozzle. This could cause severe damage to the printer (break the glass bed, bend rods, ...) and at least ruin your calibration!

Last time I had a crash like that was when, after having modded the bed, I stupidly tried to autolevel my bed without heating the nozzle... and there was a big drop of solid filament at the tip of the nozzle which was thicker than the triggering distance of the z-probe....

To avoid this, I created this z-saver thing.

  • print a pair of them,
  • screw a M4 screw on each, (a standard M4 screw will self tap the PLA)
  • clip them on the bottom of the Z axis
  • turn each screw so that the top of the screw is around 0,5 to 1 mm lower than each z carriage

Should a problem occur with the Z probe, the nozzle would still crash into the bed but only by less than 1 mm which would be harmless as the ANET allows some flexion (springs, rods, bed, springy z couplers...)... (see the video https://youtu.be/Kc9WjSo-Jfk )

Besides this security function, this thing is also quite usefull to perfectly align your Z axis. You must first trim your Z-savers to the exact same lenght using a caliper.
Then follow this procedure:

  • release all the axis (motors OFF)
  • manualy home the noozle to X min endstop
  • rotating the two Z threaded rods, move down your Z axis to come close to the z-savers
  • then continue moving in Z until each carriage comes in contact with the z-savers (a paper sheet might help)
    ==> your X axis is perfectly calibrated before bed levelling!

EDIT : I had thought to perform an automatic X axis positonning stalling the motors on the z-savers but as long as there are springy z couplers on the rods, this procedure is not accurate enough. Removing the couplers could be the way to go!

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

Supports:

No

Resolution:

print vertically
Printed in PLA, uses 2x 1.8m of filament

customize it if needed

I had in my garage some M4 screws but you may use different screws from M3 to M6 this is the reason why I give the opportunity to customize this thing.
Default values are for M4 25mm long screws

I introduce a screw diameter offset in order to trim the screw hole if they are to loose or too tight.

comments.author: zjxlsti

comments.text:
You're fully right (see first comment), the springy couplers introduce some unaccuracy when leveling up to motor stall.
There could be a higher torque given for instance by the right motor leading to a longer stretching of the right coupler that once released would place the right carriage few 1/10 of mm lower than the left one...
comments.author: zjxlsti

comments.text: Crazy question...could the limit switch be tied in series with the sensor...this way a physical clicky is still present but set lower than the actual sensor...if sensor stops good, but if not it hits the clicky and says "whoah wait a min...stop!"  vs a physical "you shall not pass" block?
comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.text:
Not that crazy... A second physical switch could indeed be wired in parallel (not serial) with the sensor output. As there is a pull up resistor at the ANET's board IO, it should work and this would prevent crashes when homing.
However I go on thinking the z-saver is safer as
comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.author: elliotboney

comments.text: I like your design, simple and effective. I didn't like how the couplers got tensioned at the end of the video, but that is a small price to pay and yours seamed to hold.
comments.author: FxDx

comments.text:
Thanks for having pointed out the elongation of the Z couplers. For an automatic calibration of the X axis, it would introduce unaccuracy.
Then it is preferable to do it manually still using the z-savers
I have edited the thing description.
comments.author: FxDx

comments.text:
Thank you!
You're right that the couplers have to balance the torque given by the motors before they stall. I'm not really concerned by the small tension they are submited as their elongation remain quite acceptable (they stay in the elastic domain and return to their original length...).
But if we use the z-savers for the X calibration process maybe the accuracy of the final position is not perfect if the both couplers and motors do not behave exactely the same (I'll have to check). There could be a higher torque given for instance by the right motor leading to a longer strechting of the right coupler that once released would place the right carriage few 1/10 of mm lower than the left one...

Quick and dirty motor soft mounts for micro quads running 11XX motors. Print with a flexible filament such as TPU or TPE. Once I added these my micro flew much smoother! Some folks say soft-mounting doesn't work, but for me it was a night and day difference. Maybe it dampens vibration, maybe it changes the frequency of vibration, I don't know, I just know it works for me and I hope it does for you too ;)

Here's me flying with them: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3446zdrCX9U&t=17s

NOTE: Be careful to use the right length motor screws, expect some compression of the pad and be sure you don't end up with your screws touching your motor windings... Ask me how I know :/

author: SummersideGuy

description.text:
This antenna cover is intended to be printed out of TPU. Use an extrusion multiplier of at least 1.15 with a layer thickness of no greater than 0.15 to strengthen the part and prevent holes in the print. Also, print in spiral vase mode with only one outer layer.

This cover slips on the bottom of your pagoda antenna, and the variable width of the print clicks it into place around the disks of the antenna, it does not need to be glued into place.
It also weighs very little (1.5 grams). The corrugated ridges in the part will help prevent fracturing of the brittle antenna PCB.

description.text:
I'm new to making buildings so if you think other sizes (wall height, door size, etc) would be helpful, leave a comment and let me know. I just made this 1/4 inch taller to help accommodate the variation in scale of minis.

This is a small bunker that should work for human size characters in the 25mm to 28mm scale. I did this in inches rather than metric and the floor tiles are 1 x 1 inch and the walls are 1 x 2.25 inch panels. The door opening is 1 inch wide and 1.75 inches high. with the roof, the total height is 2.375 inches. The roof also has a 1 inch grid.

If you want to play with the pieces I designed, here is the Tinkercad link https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jQFeIHsGCfu-bunkers-1-inch-scale
You'll find all the pieces I used to make this as well as a couple I didn't use. The roof is assembled from 3 different tile types, a center, edge and a corner. The corner pillars are there to hold the roof in place. Make sure the grid is in inches and everything should snap into place. Change the "Snap Grid" resolution to fine tune the positions.

title: Hyperlite/Floss (or other quad) Bottom Plate Skid

description.text:
I am planning on building a Hyperlite Evo, but I didn't like how, with the SMA mount on the bottom plate, the quad won't sit flat, and the SMA mount will be scuffed and damaged by landing on concrete. Two of these skids go on the underside of your quad, mounting underneath the flight controller stack. Since the mounting dimension of the larger skid is 30.5mm x 30.5mm, it can be used on other top-battery quads like the Floss. There is a smaller, 20mm x 20mm mount size skid if you are using the 20x20 mounts on the Floss 2.

After getting the frame, I realized that the skids don't need to be nearly as tall as my original versions, so I have included a skid for 30.5x30.5 mount that is half of the height of the original skids.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Since the Floss frames are supposed to be as light as possible, you may not want to print the skids at 100% infill, but they will be the most durable that way.

title: Rotating Car Charger-Holder for iPhone 4 4S with Magnets

description.text:
While most apps for iPhone are ok vertically, some apps are better used horizontally. Dashboard apps and most navigation apps can be named as examples.
The holder is held in vertical or horizontal position by small neodmium magnets.
I will post more photos after I trim the brim residues and install it in the car.

Consists of:
  • 2x printed parts
  • 8x 5mm x 5mm cylindrical neodmium magnets
  • 1x bearing 19mm outer diameter-10mm inner diameter-5mm thickness (I figured with a bearing, the holder would rotate more smoothly, but it is not really necessary. you can reduce the diameterof the cavity behing the holder to 10,2mm and exclude the bearing.)
  • 1x M2 screw
  • 1x M2 nut with plastic locker
  • 1x iphone USB cable
    • As you can see in the pictures, assembly is easy. So no instructions necessary. Just a few notes:

  • Be carefull with the polarity of the magnets when inserting them. the ones on the bracket and the ones on the holder should be inserted with opposite poles facing each other. If you insert them wrong, it may be difficult to pull them out back.
    If this happens, leave the part on the hot bed of your printer for 15-20 minutes to allow the plastic to expand and try pulling them with another magnet again.

  • It is ok, if the magnets are loose in the holes, because the screw will be holding the two parts together. Magnets' job is to keep the rotary position, not to hold the pieces together.
  • The phone is held loose in the holder. Actually it is held by the charging connector. I made it loose, to prevent the phone from getting scratched with extended use.
    • Feel free to ask any questions you may have.

comments.text:
Best iPhone car holder ever. Thanks a lot for sharing!
The screw-hole and the space for the nut are more like M3, not M2. Maybe you want to update that in the details.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kUKktjNIfvd

Bracket that attaches to a Drive brand wheelchair armrest with a slot for a strap to secure it. Two cupholder designs included, along with the interface connector if you want to design your own accessory.

Arches are a great looking element in animated Christmas light shows and this pixel strip holder will secure your pixel strips flush to the bottom of 3/4" Pex tubing.

Before you build the arches you’ll need to do some calculations first. To have a true edge to edge light on your arches you’ll want the pixel strips to reach all the way to the end of the tubing. (Being a little short is ok) Once you’ve figured out the length of the tubing and the pixel strips you will want to first predrill and tap the ends of the arch for an 8/32 size nylon machine screw. Drill the hole on the top, upward facing side of the arch about 1/2” from the ends. Then feed your pixel strip inside the arch and on one side place the pixel strip holder over the pixel strip. Next slide a 4" zip tie through the hole on the strip holder and push the pixel strip and the holder simultaneously about 2-3" deep into the arch. (Note: the zip tie is only used to pull the holder towards the end of the arch and is later removed, so there is no need to secure it) On the opposite side of the arch pull just enough of the pixel strip out to slide a pixel strip holder over the pixel strip and then push back until flush to the end of the arch. When flush with the edge of the arch, secure a nylon machine screw through the premade hole and tighten just enough for a snug fit. The nylon screw should apply pressure to the center of the mount on the flat side to securely hold in place. Now with one end of the pixel strip held firmly in place, grab the zip tie from the opposite side and pull along with the pixel strip. Once satisfied with the position and tension, secure in the same manner as the first side and discard the zip tie. When complete, clip off protruding piece of nylon screws on the outside of the Pex and secure into your base mounts. If you ever need to remove the strip holders they come apart very easily by using a small drill bit to drill out then nylon screw.

Soft Sleve that can be printed without support and raft...
Use flexible filament (TPU) - this sleeve is very tight. The idea is to have the camera covered with soft material but the mount underneath with hard material. I haven't seen a combination like this that's why I made one. The idea is to be able to switch the camera between different quads in seconds rather than having to carry zip-ties or installing mounts everywhere. I will upload fitting mounts for Hyperlite EVO HD as well as for Martian II frames. The mounts will be editable - so you can design one that fits your quad.

Monoprice Select Mini V2

No

Supports:

No

50%

Notes:

DO NOT PRINT WITH HARD FILAMENTS (PLA, ABS, ...)
You must use TPU or another flex filament.

title: Maker Select v2/Wanhao Duplicator i3 LED mount

description.text:
This is an LED strip mount that will fit a stock Monoprice Maker Select v2. It is mounted with the stock screws, so no special parts are needed. The only "custom" part is however you choose to power the LEDs. I made a little Y cable from 2-pin headers and connected it to my extruder fan connector. This has 12V whenever the printer is on, so it's perfect for the LED strip.

It is designed to hold one segment of 3528 LED strip. The wire I used is a little bit of an old ethernet cable.

Minimum layer time: 10s (I'd say 5-10s for this. I was in a hot room with stock cooling)
Minimum speed: 15mm/s

author: Nelky

description.text:
Arches are a great looking element in animated Christmas light shows and this pixel strip holder will secure your pixel strips flush to the bottom of 1" Pex tubing so you eliminate hot spots.

Before you build the arches you’ll need to do some calculations first. To have a true edge to edge light on your arches you’ll want the pixel strips to reach all the way to the end of the tubing. (Being a little short is ok) Once you’ve figured out the length of the tubing and the pixel strips you will want to first predrill and tap the ends of the arch for an 8/32 size nylon machine screw. Drill the hole on the top, upward facing side of the arch about 1/2” from the ends. Then feed your pixel strip inside the arch and on one side place the pixel strip holder over the pixel strip. Next slide a 4" zip tie through the hole on the strip holder and push the pixel strip and the holder simultaneously about 2-3" deep into the arch. (Note: the zip tie is only used to pull the holder towards the end of the arch and is later removed, so there is no need to secure it) On the opposite side of the arch pull just enough of the pixel strip out to slide a pixel strip holder over the pixel strip and then push back until flush to the end of the arch. When flush with the edge of the arch, secure a nylon machine screw through the premade hole and tighten just enough for a snug fit. The nylon screw should apply pressure to the center of the mount on the flat side to securely hold in place. Now with one end of the pixel strip held firmly in place, grab the zip tie from the opposite side and pull along with the pixel strip. Once satisfied with the position and tension, secure in the same manner as the first side and discard the zip tie. When complete, clip off protruding piece of nylon screws on the outside of the Pex and secure into your base mounts. If you ever need to remove the strip holders they come apart very easily by using a small drill bit to drill out then nylon screw.

description.text: just a nude girl lithophanes

Smartphone Smart Spring Stand is an elegant design in one piece - just bend the holder and snap on the phone, the spring part locks it in place and makes a solid stand.

The holder is almost invisible but solid and allows for the easy access to screen and buttons.

It's just as easy to remove it again, just squeeze the sides and the holder releases the phone.

When not used, it can become completely flat and is very easy to bring with you wherever you go ;-)

Tested with:

  • Huawei P10 (+ with case)
  • Nokia 3 (+ with case)

Update: Added models when phone is in hard cover (case). Models are named "With Case".

I also made this so it could be scalable and so a Raspberry Pi or and Arduino could fit inside, you will need to scale it to fit those if you want to use it this way. title: Goldie Delicious' Brooch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Way back in s4e9 of MLP, Goldie Delicious's brooch struck me as kind of a neat design, and I expected the fandom to make one, but never saw one.

Fast forward to about a month ago, and as I was doing some learning with FreeCAD and experimenting, I decided to see if I could make my own. Extracted the brooch from a larger vector, did some import and clean up, some test prints to work out the relief, then threw some acrylic on. Up close the errors in my paint job are painfully obvious, but I'm pretty happy with the result.

There's two versions of the file - The brooch in the show has an eyelash, but scaled to 40mm across the major axis my printer only does a little nub in the center, which doesn't look good, so I re-exported without it. You're free to try it either way.

Big thanks to GEZawaTT over on Deviantart for the vector. (https://gezawatt.deviantart.com/art/Goldie-Delicious-with-her-cats-429167706)

description.text:
This is a remix of ccrumpackers version. I printed his and found it to be too large, using too much plastic for my liking. I looked at others and they were all quite large, compared to the real McCoy!

I used m4 bolts, but had to trim the ends off them to make them fit. I could fix it in the design I guess, to use std sizes, but mine is made now!

Printer:

Modified Geeetech Pro C

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

I used 100% since it is small, to make it strong.

Notes:

I printed it in PLA to get sharp edges and no warping. Needed to sand down the track parts a bit to get a good slide going.

I found a picture of the real McCoy on the web, downloaded it and attached it to a fusion design as as a canvas. I found the length of it on the sellers site and calibrated the canvas to that length. then it was just making a sketch and extruding the parts and adding the internals based on ccrumpackers design. I am pleased with the way it turned out!

remixed_from.title: FlashAir WiFi Dust Cap For FlashForge Creator Pro

description.text:
I started with LarzJ 's FlashAir WiFi Dust Cap and made it a little taller. It now fits on my QiDi Tech 1 3D printer as a dust cap for the Toshiba Flash Air SD card.

When I printed and tried the original version it popped out the SD card. Apparently an SD card in the QiDi's SD card slot projects upward slightly more than when in the FFCP.

I used the two color version (c'mon, it is for a QiDi Dual Extruder printer...) and stretched the Z axis on both parts a bit in S3D. I also moved the base of the Logo up a bit to produce a flush top surface. Then exported the STL's.

print_settings.Notes:: Print 2x endcaps, 1x shaft.

description.text: This is a bobbin that is compatible with Majacraft spinning wheels, specifically the Pioneer. Majacraft uses a 5/16in shaft. This should spin freely, if not, increase the spool_shaft_clearance in the SCAD file by 1mm, or use a drill.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this in PLA with a 1MM volcano nozzle. This gave a great speed benefit, but wasn't necessary.

Print 2x endcaps, 1x shaft.

The endcaps have a very loose fit over the shaft piece, so be prepared to fill with epoxy or use a 3D printing pen to fill it. I also used the 3d printing pen to run a bead of plastic along the inside of the endcap, to ensure the shaft never detaches.

author: SpurdoTheDwarf

title: Old School Runescape - The Helm of Raedwald

description.text:
Crack the clue was released between June and July of 2016 in Old School Runescape. Players were given four clues over four weeks to find pieces of an in game equipment set. After the fourth clue was released, players could combine the information from all four clues to create and solve an incredibly difficult fifth clue leading to the final piece of the set, The Helm of Raedwald. The first player to discover the helm would be forever commemorated in game.

It went undiscovered for almost a year, until in mid 2017 user Pikachu Yip successfully located and obtained the helm.

I am in no way affiliated with Jagex Game Studios. The content provided is purely for entertainment/enjoyment purposes.

description.text:
Go to thepooter dot com to see the original and how it works.

I saw the videos on YouTube and wanted one immediately, 3D Printer to the rescue!! Still plan to order one though!

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.175

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I've not printed the TPU outer but I added it on request from someone. I believe the TPU outer will actually work better than an inner tube as the inner tube allows for too much stretch but again I've not had a chance to test it.

The pla caps are the only parts that should need supports. I printed at 100% infill but with 1.2mm shells but I really think 50% is more than enough. Your mileage my vary.

Assembly

I assembled this with foam rubber inside for more rigidity and spring back. This is needed to give firmness when pushing the pooter into the ball of your hand to get a good seal. The outer on my original is a standard bike inner tube cut to roughly 1.5" long and the caps are gel super glued into the tube.

title: Cartridge - Cricut Paper Cutting Machine George Cartridge

description.text:
This Thing shows how to make a Cricut Paper Cutting Machine George Cartridge. The George Cartridge is is the basic cartridge that most Cricut Paper Cutting machines come with. Sometimes people lose the cartridge making the machine inoperable. You can purchase a cartridge from Cricut or make this one.

To make this cartridge you will need to 3D print the shell in PLA and then make the small PC Board by cutting the finger area off of an old PC ISA Card. ISA style cards are now obsolete and should be easy to find. Cut the small board to 28 mm by 20 mm using a Hacksaw. You should end up with 10 fingers on each side of the PC board. Using the photo I provided, solder jumpers on both sides of the board which makes the cartridge work when plugged in in either direction. Test the PC board you made with your Cricut before you assemble it with the shell. I have provided photos of an actual George Cartridge in case my instructions are not clear.

If you need a keyboard overlay, you may purchase the Cricut Universal Overlay for $5 here:
https://www.amazon.com/Cricut-Universal-Overlay-for-Cartridge/dp/B00E0IPZIA

Use Super Glue Glue to glue the PC board in the slot of the shell. Make sure the PC board is flush with the end of the shell and then glue the two halves of the shell together. Be careful to not get any glue on the fingers and definitely wait until the glue is dry before inserting the cartridge into your Cricut.

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm or 0.2 mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Be sure to use supports
PLA is suggested so that Super Glue can be used for assembly

title: Ellsworth Style Bowl Gouge Grinding Jig for Woodturning

description.text:
This is a simple Ellsworth style grinding jig I made to fit a Hurricane 5/8" bowl gouge. Just add a threaded rod/cut bolt and a thumb screw. I have a bunch of them. I was so glad to print since that allows you to make a round hole with a flat top that keeps the gouge from rotating. If you make this by hand with wood or aluminum, the gouge can rotate in the hole, which makes you grind more metal each time if the angle isn't perfectly matched each time you go to sharpen. this jig has helped me stretch my gouges out a lot longer!
See my work at www.wildtypewoodoworks.com
I had a problem where my print service made it too small when scaling it into their printer. so I just redrew it with a larger hole. Ill post that as a separate item.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Unfortunately I had this printed by a free local service so I had no control over it. It was printed with a MakerBot, but thats all I know. I had to make a second version enlarging the hole. Ill post that as a separate item. It printed infilled but I would have preferred solid. I drilled a hole and filled with some spare epoxy actually so I could thread it.

tap both small holes with a 1/4-20 tap. cut the head off a long 1/4-20 bolt or thread rod and cut to length for your gridning jig. Mine is about 4.5 inches total. the long rod goes in the 45 degree face.
the other small hole you tap for 1/4-20 is perpendicular to the main whole. Put a 1/4-20 thumb screw in that hole to tighten your gouge up against the flat surface.
This keeps the gouge from rotating when you re-insert it.
sketched on paper, drawn in Autocad. This is my first CAD drawing ever made.

title: CR-10 Heavy Duty customisable modular e3D V6 mount Volcano 5015 ABL

description.text:
CR-10 Heavy Duty Modular E3D V6 Mount

This is a mount for the V6 hot-end by E3D that is stronger and more rigid than some of the mounts that are out there. This mount also comes with an array of possible options for any extra functionality as attachments on the sides.

The minimum you will need to print out is the body and one of the faceplates. There are a variety of wings for different combinations, additions and customizations.

NOTE: Only left side parts are in the library of wings. To print a wing for the right side simply mirror the part in your slicer.

Current modules

  • 5015 fan mount
  • ABL (18mm thread). Offset X:(+/-) 41.5mm / Y:0
  • 5015 fan & ABL (18mm thread). Do not use on left side. Offset X: -63mm / Y:0
  • 5015 fan & ABL alt (18mm thread). Offset X:(+/-) 63mm / Y:12mm
  • BLTouch mount. Offset X: (+/-) 33.265 mm / Y: -1.00 mm
  • BLTouch & 5015 fan mount. Offset X: (+/-) 58.565 mm / Y: -11.00 mm
  • 30mm heatsink fan mount
  • 40mm heatsink fan mount

Remix

Based on the V6 mount by graham01
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2471011
and the dual 5015 fan mod by RebelRousingProps
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2274499

I found some issues with the V6 mount file, also missing was support for dual 5015 fans and an ABL sensor so decided to make my own. I've also made my own library of parts.

If you would like to use a 40mm heatsink fan and don't want to use the integrated ones I've made. Then you can use this part https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:929326 which works great with this mount.

special shout out to Chris Ragucci who helped me test these parts and provide feedback.

Update 1

  • Fixed the 5015 fan wings. correct measurements, centred with hot-end
  • ABL sensor mount also centred, ie Y offset = 0
  • Minor improvements to Mount body

Update 2

  • Optimised wings to not need as many supports (needs new body)
  • Created new body with better mounting to x-carriage and updated wing rails
  • NEW PART: 30mm fan mount (40mm version to come soon)

Update 3

  • Fixed a minor issue with the face plate
  • Optimised the V6 30mm heatsink fan mount faceplate
  • NEW PART: 40mm heatsink fan mount faceplate

Update 4

  • Removed logo (wouldnt print correctly)

Update 5

  • Updated 40mm fan mount - shouldn't blow air on to heat block (needs testing)

Update 6 (major update)

  • added holes back to the rear of the body for more compatibility
  • resized holes for nuts, made them tighter as they were too loose and not being held correctly
  • fixed clearance tolerance for heat sink, it now goes in tight without having to be forced in
  • Added logo for e3D and V6 to face place to help with orientation during assembly. Fan mount version didn't require it but added for consistency
  • NEW FILE: Added new STEP file of the wing base so people can create their own wings

Update 7

  • NEW PART: new version of the 5015 fan mount with ABL. ABL mount has been moved forward 12mm. this is mainly because the origianl ver, when used on the left side, hits the gantry

Update 8

  • NEW PART: V6 Volcano mount (needs testing). fully compatible with all wing modules, covers and heatsink fan mounts

Update 9

  • NEW PART: New mount for BLTouch (might do fan combo later). Note that the BLTouch sits in the arm as per the image. This so the sensor sits at the height indicated by the spec and leaves enough room for the screw that secures the moudule to the body
  • NEW PART: V6 mount designed for aluminium casting. Such as shown in these Youtube vids

Update 10 - 4th Oct 17

  • Reworked all the parts, cleaned them up
  • Improved vertical position in rails
  • Fan duct has been updated to blow air more on that part than the nozzle

Update 10.5 - 5th Oct 17

  • Fixed some oversights and minor improvements
  • ADDED: new and improved casting versions

Update 11 - 31st Oct 17

  • NEW PART: LED bracket mount - attaches to fans
  • NEW PART: 5015 fan mount with BLTouch (3rd Nov)
  • UPDATE: 40mm Fan mount - added more material
  • REMOVED: Aluminium loss casting mounts - people incorrectly using them
  • All parts now have version numbers, As of now starting at V1

Update 12 - 3rd Nov

  • UPDATED: all 5015 fan ducts now blow air lower and away from the nozzle
  • NEW PART: 5015 fan mount with BLTouch (updated with fix 6th nov)

Known issues

None

Printer:

CR-10

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Most parts can be printed with the above settings. For orientation please look a the screen shot in the gallery.

The only part that needs support is the main body that attaches to the x-carriage.

#Assembly

  1. Attach the wing of your choice to the body

    • 1x M3 Nyloc nut
    • 1x M3 12mm screw

    The wings are adjustable in height (11mm total) and should never go past the tip of the hotend. Place the nut down the holes in the body and secure the wing using a screw from the side of the wing

    1a. 5015 wing - Attach the Fan

    • 1x M3 20mm screw
    • 1x M3 Nyloc nut

    You can drop the nut through the top part of the mount and then slide into the nut shaped hole. lineup the fan and secure with the 20mm screw.

    1b. ABL wing
    Follow the instructions of your ABL. Take note of which side your sensor is, the offset settings are

    • 5015 ABL wing: X:63.00 mm Y:0
    • 5015 ABL wing alt: X:63.00 mm Y:12
    • ABL only wing: X:41.50 mm Y:0

  2. Attach the body to the x-carriage

    • 2x M3 Nyloc nuts

    These need to be put in place before you mount the body to the x-carriage. Then use the existing screws to screw the body in place. NOTE The stock screws that come with the hotend and x-carriage might not be the best quality. It's optional to replace these. To do so you'll need:

    • 2x M3 6mm screws
    • 1x M3 20mm screw

  3. Attach the front plate

    • 2x M3 30mm screws
    • Fan mount 4x M3 16mm+ screws (came with V6)

    Insert the top part of the V6 heatsink and attach the front plate to the body with the screws. these should screw into the nuts you placed in the back of the body.
    If you're attaching a fan mount, you can use the screws that came with the V6 fan, but you may need longer ones depending on how thick your fan is. Note that these screws have a drilling tread that grips the plastic

I like the concept and installation was ok. I do however have some design tips for you.
The inductive sensor mount "wing" is a bit flimsy to my tastes and it does in no way have to be as they are just as capable of gripping a much thicker holder. I suggest doubling or tripling the thickness of the "ring" to make it more rigid.

comments.text: Just for reference to those who use marlin. Marlin does not do floating points for probe offsets so when setting your probe offset and if your using a mount for instance BLtouch which has depending on side of the hotend an offset of +- 33.265mm. In this case you can either enter 33 or round up to 34 otherwise your compiling will error out. This is a negligible amount so don't worry about it.

comments.text:
I also have this issue. with the latest wings, radial fan on each side. No sock on the E3D Volcano (yet, here it two days)
This is what I did for a temp fix:
Turned on the part fans: M106
Ran PID Tuning 10 ttimes for 5 degrees over what the nozzle was going to run at: M303 E0 S200 C10
Took the resulting k values and saved them in the EEPROM
M301 P29.75 I2.16 D102.36 (your values may be different)
M500 (to save)

comments.text:
With the silicon boot on the heater bloc, the fans at 100% did not affect the temperature at all. Your heater bloc should always be lagged no matter what part cooling system you use. Even with the fans aiming away from the heater bloc, the movement of air they generate will inevitably cause disruption to the heater bloc temperatures if you don't lag it.
I tried with and without a silicon sock, Without, the bloc lost 10C in about 5 seconds and continued to lose temperature all the way down to well below the printing temp of the filament. With, the bloc remained at the chosen temperature.
comments.author: jasonbrent

comments.text: That's a good question; In this case, it isn't the bed as I'm about 300mm up in the print. The print itself is in vase mode, so it has external surface area, but the internal area is just a "Capture point" for air and not a reflection point... I tried to see if I could use "smoke" from my vape to look at the air currents to answer that question, but without a high speed camera, I don't think I can reliably answer that. When this print is finished, I need to do a couple of PID tunes on my head anyway, so I'll move the gantry to ~300mm and see what it looks like with/without the fans and update. That should eliminate bed and print bounce.
comments.author: chito

comments.text: Try using a bowl of water with the unheated nozzle just above the surface, then turn on the fans slightly and see where the air hits.  I think ideally the flow would hit directly under the tip with no upward reflections.  Granted, air flow from two directions colliding in the middle has to go somewhere, so forward, backward, and up (toward the nozzle) would make sense.  Hopefully more forward and backward given the downward angle of the source flow.

comments.text: It's been a while since I looked @ the Marlin code to try to figure out why I was getting reset/shutdowns but I'm pretty sure it was the thermal protection code that is supposed to catch either the thermistor coming loose or going bad to prevent possible fires.  I think you need to increase the temp range or increase the time so it doesn't trigger.
comments.author: jasonbrent

comments.text: Yup, PID tuned to 250C, 10 times, about half a mm off the bed to ensure I'd get reflective air, fans at 100%... no problem at all. The head is covered in silicone as someone else suggested, but I don't have any kapton tape around. For now, the fix was simply to use a heat gun to slightly change the airflow. In effect, I "squished" the airflow by taking the top of the exhaust vent and compressing it slightly while simultaneously taking the bottom of the exhaust vent and rolling it down a tad. That fixed the immediate problem I was having.

comments.text: You're changing the hotend, so it's not the same size as the stock one. so you'll have to adjust your machine and thats normal. Another problem is that peoples beds are levelled differently. So changing the mount might help you but they stuff up other people. the standard solution is to print an adjustable z-limit switch mount. Join any of the Cr-10 facbook groups and you can post any issues there. someone is bound to help you out
comments.author: DarkApollo

comments.text: No, you're not understanding what he's saying, I'm getting the same issue.  When using this mount, the nozzle tip sits higher than the original did, such that the bed has to come up higher.  The bed can only come up so high though, as the springs are only so long.  The only other option is to bring the z axis down, but what he's saying is that the plate assembly that holds the x axis arm onto the z axis lead screw hits the yellow stepper motor retaining part, so it can only go so low.  The tolerance between the bed being able to be adjusted up and the z axis being able to be adjusted down is very small.  Because there is very little tension on the springs due to the bed having to be so high, it's difficult to maintain proper level.  The issue with this mount is that it clips over the x axis bracket but doesn't mount the hot end low enough.

comments.text: First I want to say great job on the V6 mount.  I've tried 2 or 3 different ones and yours is by far the best.  However I'm having problems with the 5015 fan mounts with a sensitive PLA filament that has poor layer bonding at lower temps.  I've got the fan mounts set as low as they can go and they are at the perfect height so the nozzle is lower than the fan ducts.  It appears that the ducts are blowing air on the nozzle/heater block.  With dual fans @ 100% my nozzle temp drops from 220 to 205 when the fans turn on even with a heater block sock on.  If I drop the fan speed down to 40% then the nozzle is able to maintain close to 220 and have a decent print.  The problem is the fans start to whine at lower speeds.  I've verified it's the fans by turning the fans off in the slicer and monitoring the nozzle temps.
comments.author: DIYorDIE

comments.text: The V6 comes with silicone socks for this exact reason, also I'm reviewing parts of my designs and I've noticed that the fans could benefit from being a little bit lower. You will always get some air on the heatblock. Your printer should detect the temp drop and heat up the block and compensate. I'm also looking at other fan duct designs like a radial (Prusa i3 mk3)
comments.author: DIYorDIE

comments.text: I think two 5015 @ 100% causes too much heat loss for the CR10 to keep up.  I had to cut both fans by 60% to maintain proper temp but that causes problems printing Benchy.  I've only had the V6 for a few days but I've been scratching my head trying figure out what was going on.  Only today did I notice the temperature drop.

comments.text: depends really. for everyday stuff like pla, abs, petg then a pla mount should be fine. The Heatsink shouldn't get too hot if everything is working correctly. If you plan on having an enclosure and will print high temp filaments then a pla, abs or petg mount might not cut it. the best filament for heat based stuff seems to be nylon which falls apart at around 245C. If you're in the Facebook user groups for the CR-10 there is run being organised for just the mount to be machined from Aluminium which melts at 660C and is stronger, really light and shiny lol

comments.text:
For the left side 5015 probe mount shouldn't it be Offset X: -63mm (not +63 since that is right not left for neg) / Y: 12mm, also why is Y 12 not zero like if was right side mount since it's just a mirror object. Also get a compile error of "exit status 1
static assertion failed: RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION can't be reached by the Z probe." when compiling it as:
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -63 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 12 (or zero) // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]
comments.author: cyris69

comments.text: the offset in this case is 63mm along the x axis. so if you have printed it for left side it would be -63 if you have printed it for the right its +63
comments.author: cyris69

comments.text: It should be -12, I believe as marlin seems to define "negative for Y as closer to the front of the machine.. I'm using -63 and -12 and it seems to be working as I'd expect.

comments.author: BotYoyo

comments.text:
I've printed it in pla. the side wing modules should be fine in pla. not sure about the main body. the mount is also designed to allow airflow behind the heatsink so hot air can get out easier. I bought the v6 so I could use a wider range of enginnering filaments, which means higher temps. I really wonder if it will warp if you print the mount in pla. if the heatsink and fan are doing their job it shouldn't get hot enough for that to happen. maybe print using a filament with better thermal properties. you could always anneal your pla and that will make it way tougher upto 160C i think, top of the line is nylon which wont budge till around 230C but is super hard to print with (needs hight temps and warps)
i would love to know if anyone has had any warping issues with pla
comments.author: BotYoyo

comments.text: I've used the previous version in PLA up to 250c and no problems at all

description.text:
I had a problem and I needed a solution, since we enjoy flying the DJI Spark so much we ordered second set of props as once in a while we cut a little grass and having a spare set on hand is just a good thing but they just came in these flimsy cardboard boxes which provided no protection. The solution, well design and 3D print a protective box! So here you DJI Spark owners go! Also if you have any suggestions for improvement, please leave me a comment below and is there anything else you would like to see designed for the spark?

What you don't have an extra set of props! Well check these out http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com/dji-spark-props/ also check out our DJI Spark Accessory page here:http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com/dji-spark-accessories/ as we track the DJI Spark Market for all new comers!

Major Favor: if you make one of these please post a MAKE and share it with the community :-) .

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Printer:

Any 200mm x 200mm printer will work

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Simple print!

title: An Arakh, the preferred weapon of the "Horselords" as seen on TVs "Game of Thrones"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Dothraki are nomadic horse-mounted warriors, who sweep across the vast central plains of Essos in search of plunder. Most of their society is centered around their horses: even their name for themselves in their own language, "Dothraki", literally means "riders"

The Dothraki traditionally fight with curved swords known as arakhs, and also employ bolas, daggers, and whips, or huge, recurved bows with impressive range and striking power that can be fired from horseback.

Source - http://gameofthrones.wikia.com/wiki/Dothraki

This Arakh was printed at .2 mm resolution with 20% infill. It comes with
a horse head is on the end of the handle and symbols on the blade.

At 27" inches in length and 1.2 inches in diameter, it looks are awe inspiring.

This kit is easy to assemble, very little work required to have a finished weapon in less than hour.
Be sure to use a high quality glue for plastics.

This is not the Khal version, but a more common riders version.

You may wish to make it your own.

I wrapped the one shown in the image with jute rope, something I would expect them to have.

I also painted the emblems, regular model paint, but it will need several layers to look solid.

Be a Dothraki warrior at the next CON

Assemble and add the emblems of your tribe.

title: Telescope Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this mount for my telescope to take pictures of the eclipse, and the results are amazing! Shot with a small kit telescope, with a magnification of 35x, I was even able to see sunspots. Here's a timelapse of the eclipse through my phone https://youtu.be/1nUuXQIDXN8.

This adapter uses a new screw mechanism compared to the old one from my other design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477689). It's an inverse of Canon's DSLR lens attaching mechanism. After multiple failed attempts of making a proper thread with my rotary tool (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2490290), out of impatience, I decided to try a screw-on piece that didn't require a high resolution for faster prototyping. This new design only requires 1/3 of a turn to fit on, making it very easy to swap out with other lenses if needed.

*Note
This case is specific for the galaxy s7 edge.

Depending on the popularity of this, I may make a proper universal adapter using the screw design and adapter pieces for common binoculars.

More pictures of the eclipse are on my website: souzou

title: Qidi X-One Blower Fan Duct and Mount

description.text:
This is a new version of the blower fan bracket and blower fan duct.

Heavily based on these two designs:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2139368
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086927

Features:

  • A place to secure the cable bundle with a zip tie.
  • Recessed hex holes for M3 nuts.
  • Walls that hug the cooling bar to reduce bracket movement.
  • Easier to access mounting points for the fan duct.
  • Curvier fan duct.
  • Parametric Solidworks files.

I don't really expect the fan duct to perform better in any measurable way (JP's fan duct was already much better than the stock fan duct). However, now that I have this in Solidworks, I can play around with fan duct designs much easier. Also, it should be a little easier to swap out the duct now that the mounting points easier to get at.

Long term, I would like to try magnetic mounts for the fan duct. And maybe some kind of wrap around duct.

Companion to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2490406

Update 08-24-17:
Added another duct variant that is a little bit further away from the heater block and with a slightly larger opening that is pointing down more. (I haven't printed this one yet)

Update 08-28-17:
Also works with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502216

"Good design is as little design as possible." This principal of Dieter Rams' has stuck with me as I design. My goal is to think about products in their most basic forms to prevent distraction and disruption as you work and live.

With this project, I wanted to create a timekeeping device that had all the parts to function, without the extra clutter to be functional, yet simple.

This along with all my other design projects are designed in Autodesk Fusion 360. It is a free cloud based modeling software that enables you to develop ideas and into physical products. Click the link below to download a free trial of the software. I don’t think you’ll regret it. Download for free --> http://autode.sk/2sx9WHh

My desktop machine of choice is Boxzy CNC. It is a versatile 3 in 1 tool that gives you a new level of possibility that didn't exist before in a 3d printer or desktop CNC machine.
Get 5% off on your Boxzy machine by using code "clock" at checkout
https://www.boxzy.com

How I made this project: https://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-3D-Printed-Clock/

description.text: Spool holder for the MakerBot Replicator+

print_settings.Notes:: Use whatever resolution you prefer. For the plate I've used 0.2mm and for the clamp I've used 0.1mm. I printed mine in PLA+ to allow some flex when inserting the controller. It's a tight fit so if the material is too rigid it's likely to snap.

description.text:
This is a mount for the DJI Mavic Pro controller to allow it to use the RAM mount system (B size). It should work on the Spark too, but I'm not sure.

The mounting plate is a separate piece which allows for different mounting options if required. The dimensions for the plate if creating your own are:
Outer rectangle: 35.60mm square x 1.4mm thick
Inner rectangle: 29.60mm square x 2.0mm thick

My use case is to use it in Active Track mode whilst cycling, but I haven't tried it out on the bike yet. I'd recommend using a tether just in case it breaks.

Update 29/8/17: I've now included a plate with a GoPro style mount on it. This should work with any GoPro mounting setup.

Update 02/10/17: I've now been able to test the clamp and it worked perfectly (ie it didn't break when used on a road bike!).

Printer:

Kodama Trinus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Use whatever resolution you prefer. For the plate I've used 0.2mm and for the clamp I've used 0.1mm. I printed mine in PLA+ to allow some flex when inserting the controller. It's a tight fit so if the material is too rigid it's likely to snap.

Remove the supports and file the mounting plate so it will fit in the hole. Glue the plate in and add some foam (or similar) to the top clips to improve the hold and avoid scratching the controller when inserting it.

This model stand is designed to work for indoor models with a motor tube/stick width between ~1/8" and 5/16". It's based off of an original design by Cezar Banks.

To make it you'll need to print 2 side pieces and 1 base pieces. You'll also need some 1/32" music wire, 3/16" dowel, 5/16" brass tube, and adhesive backed felt. To clamp the stand you just slide the small piece of brass tube up. I have mine set up so it's a light friction fit on my F1D motor tubes when unclamped. This allows me to place or remove my model from the stand with only one hand. When clamped it has a strong grasp of the model.

This is a Customer Wall plate for a dimmer switch.

"One ring to rule them all"

Part on the end of the rail of a Whirlpool dishwasher, WDT710PAYM0. I could purchase the entire rail assembly, but only the plastic part was busted. Sure, the rail which included the piece I needed is only $30 online, but I like the challenge. This was my first complex model I made from scratch. I used the free sketchup and learned a TON. It took me 3 tries to model it correctly and 5 tries to get it to print properly. All in all, a fun project.

You will need to drill out the old part to remove it from the metal rail. You can see in the side by side photo the hole I put into the plastic peg on the old broken part which holds the plastic peg to the metal rail. thought I might need to melt the knobby end of the new part to secure it to the metal rail but it snaps on the rail nicely and doesn't move. The gray part on the end swivels side to side, so you can remove the rack if needed. That wasn't broken so I didn't model it.

I updated this on 1/6/2018 with "try 3". This has been strengthened in several spots. The first I uploaded broke in the exact same place the original did, so obviously there's a weakness in the design. I've been using this latest revision for several months and even with the hot water and made from only PLA it's working like a champ.

title: Prusa MK2s Raspberry Pi V2 Camera Holder

description.text:
I wanted a design that would do a better job hiding the raspberry pi camera cable. This design routs the cable downward through the body and base, and then has a cable holder you can glue on to send the cable towards the back of the printer. You still end up with the cable loose under the bed, because there's no way around that, but it's at least a little neater than the other designs I've seen because it stays nicely under the bed

I also wanted a design that wouldn't move and didn't have any parts that would wear out, and I was willing to give up a few axis of freedom to achieve that. This design gives you full control over the yaw, rough control over the height, but no control over the pitch/roll.

Also, this isn't strictly a remix but it is based on the design of the following camera mount:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2352964

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The threads on this should be large enough that you can use any resolution you want.

Depending on your printer's dimensional accuracy, you might have problems fitting the body+chamfer into the body holder. I personally had to file the body down and then pound them in with a rubber mallet.

I actually kind of liked that, because I know it's not going anywhere

Step 0 - Optional : Attach cable holder to base

Glue a cable holder onto the base. You should glue it perpendicular to the straight section of the base, as close to the hex cutout as you can get it.

It should be parallel to the head bed, when the base is installed on the Y carriage.

Step 1 - Attach base to printer

Attach the base to the printer's Y carriage at the front right. You'll take off the screw holding the heatbed to the carriage, and put this below the Y carriage. You'll need a longer M3 screw, you can find one in the extras bag.

The final ordering should be screwhead -> base -> Y carriage -> Headbed riser -> Headbed.

You'll also want to do a test slide of your Y carriage / heatbed to ensure you've installed the base in such a way as to not hit anything. If you do, just loosen the screw and move it until it doesn't.

Step 2 - Attach camera body holder & chamfer to the body holder

Stick the camera body + chamfer into the body holder base. Depending on how dimensionally accurate your printer is, you might have to do some filing to get things to fit.

I had to file the camera body and then hammer the piece in with a rubber mallet. I didn't fix this because I like the tight fit for these pieces.

Also, the cable management slot is asymmetric, so make sure the chamfer goes into the side with the smaller gap (Otherwise you'll partially obstruct the cable management slot, but I would guess the cable will still fit because it's so thin).

Step 3 - Screw The Body Holder to the Base

Take the completed (body + chamfer + body holder) assembly and screw it into the base. Get roughly the height you want, angle it roughly where you want it to go, and use the holder nut to secure it in place (the holder nut should be tightened to the base to lock it in place. It can go above or below the base, but you might have to screw it onto the body assembly before you screw the body assembly into the base if you want the nut on top)

Step 4 - Route the Cable & Install the Camera

Route the camera cable down through the body assembly (and forward through the optional cable holder if you added one), and then route it through the printer to your Raspberry Pi. You can do it this however you want, but I personally went straight back under the Z frame, and then had the camera cable follow the PSU cables to the left. You can do it however you like, but make sure you leave enough slack in the cable for the bed to move all the way backward / forward.

At this point, you can put the camera into the camera holder, and stick on the back lid. The back lid should stay on with just a friction hold, and the camera itself shouldn't need to be screwed in because it isn't going anywhere in the case.

When you're attaching the camera lid, be careful not to unseat the little cable connector on the front of the camera. If you're having problems with the brightness on your camera, you've probably either wedged that tiny front connector lose, or you've messed up the camera cable connection at the bottom. Lid needs to go in straight for everything to work.

If you do mess it up, just turn the pi off, fix it, and restart the pi. Everything should be fine.

The diameter of the button is 14mm so if you need to resize it just play with the scale. I have also attached the Solidworks file I used if you want to edit this. To paint this, I first used 1-3 coats of gold acrylic modeling paint. After letting this dry, I used 2-3 coats of dark red enamel. I then covered the whole print with 3-5 coats of glossy spray lacquer. To attach the button I used super glue.

Additional parts you need,
