description.text:
Well, one piece if you ignore the 75 airsoft pellets and the optional spice ring. With this ultra-low profile turntable, the bearing balls roll directly on any hard, flat surface. Turn any plate or bowl into a lazy susan. Or add the optional spice ring and organize your spice cabinet. It uses 6mm airsoft pellets as bearing balls that snap securely into the ball track. I've included a 150mm turntable (shown) and a smaller 100mm turntable as well.

And by popular demand, for those of us with, um, less than pristine counter tops, I've included an optional base that will keep the balls from getting gunked up.

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

If you like you can print with zero top layers to expose the infill pattern as I have done for an interesting visual effect.

The 150mm turntable requires 75 airsoft pellets and the 100mm turntable requires 47 pellets. Just snap them into the track, and you are ready to spin.

To use it as a spice organizer (or other things that may want to fly off), snap on the matching size "spice" ring.

title: Remixed Waist for Knight Titan Poseable Legs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created a version of the waist piece with a flat top (instead of the ball/socket design compatible with the official GW plastic kit). This allows for these legs to work with any number of alternative torsos which might be missing the receiving socket required by the original waist. This allows these excellent legs to be used more broadly.

I can't afford to purchase and paint every knight configuration that I would like; these make terrific battlefield decorations and diorama pieces. I'd like GW to continue releasing new plastic kits, so I try to buy the ones I want to actually play with and paint! Consider doing the same :).

description.text:
This is a laptop stand that allows you to raise the screen to eye level and use an external keyboard. It is also stable and equipped with a 120mm fan for cooling....you do have to start with a cheap aluminum frame:
https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20170821222641&SearchText=laptop+stand
(scroll down to find the cheapest frame of the type used in the design)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The design is thin so it requires little to no infill, so use 100% for maximum stability.

Requiremens and Assembly

Once printed, glue some soft pads on the front and possibly inside the grooves for the leg support if the fit is not tight or the legs turn too easily.

Without the pads, you may scratch the back of your laptop, especially if the back is a metal alloy.

Assemble with 3x M3x8mm screws + washers
Use 120mm Fan + grill for the cooling. Attach the grill only on the top of the fan with 2 self-cutting screws. Use the button holes to attach the fan to the assembly with 2x m3x40mm screws. You will need heavy duty washers here.

Print 2 tips for the legs. Pull off the plastic end caps that came with the frame (may need force) and replace them with the tips. Then glue the caps back with epoxy. Make sure that the tips can rotate freely, so they are not glued down too. Use padding on the back of the tips too to protect your hand rest on the laptop.

You can assemble and disassemble the stand in 3-5 minutes and it folds away neatly for travel.

The fan works off 12 volts. Use any electrical hookup that you have at hand. I suggest using a 6-9V DC source for quiet operation. 5V may not be enough to start the fan, so you will have to push it manually to start and it should keep spinning at a very low RPM.

This is an enclosure for a Duet Paneldue 5" V2 display based on Davids design.
Meant to be mounted on a 2020-type profile.
Backpanel can be mounted upside down.
Top and bottom have ventilation holes.
Cabling goes through the backpanel.
Slot for SD card, USB connector is accessible, 2 holes in the front for reset and erase buttons.
Screws are all 3mm self tapping.

I made it in PETG and of course with my preferred 0,6mm nozzled Volcano ;)
Layers :
Frontpanel : 0,4mm and 0,2mm for the first 2mm on the display side (use 2 profiles in S3D)
Backpanel : 0,4mm

No support needed.
